description:
Dice Command is a semi-abstract tactical wargame for 2-4 players.  Each game players will go head-to-head in a tug of war style battle.  To fuel the War Machine, players carefully build up their army and technology while simultaneously adjusting to the movements of their opponents on the battlefield.  Deciding when to attack and when to defend can mean the difference between victory and defeat.  To win the game, players must fight through their opposing player's forces and claim that opponent's barracks!

—description from the publisher

It's lockdown time. The PQltistes rush to the supermarket to burgle the last packs of toilet paper and make offerings to the One-who-sleeps-on-the-Throne. You're one of these cultists and your goal is to make the biggest offering and be saved from the lockdown.

PQltistes contains 55 cards: cards numbered 2-10, with two 2s, three 3s, etc. and 1 police card. Shuffle these cards, then spread them out face down on the table. On your turn, choose a card and turn it face up. You can stop here, collect all the cards you've revealed, and end your turn, or you continue turning cards face up. If you reveal the police card or a card with a number that's already face up, you must gather all face-up cards and three face-down cards from the table, shuffle them, then place them wherever you want on the table. Your turn then ends.

Some cards when revealed give you the ability to peek at a face-down card or swap a card in your collection with a card in someone else's collection.

When five or fewer cards are face down on the table at the end of someone's turn, the game ends. Each card is worth 0-2 rolls of toilet paper as depicted on those cards. Additionally, you score points equal to the number of which you have the most tiles, e.g. if you have four 8s and three or fewer of each other number, you score a bonus of 8 points. In case of a tie for most tiles, you score the lower value.

Whoever has the most rolls wins!

Components:Epidemic Prevention Cards x 55

Double side cards: the light color side is called epidemic prevention card; another side with deep color frame is called infected card.

Setting:
1. Shuffle all the cards (the prevention side face up) as a deck and place it in the middle of the table.
2. Leave two spaces as the “infected area” and “discard area” next to the deck.

Playing the Game:
Start with the start player. On player’s turn, he activates the following phases in order:
After a player activates “Epidemic Prevention and Spread Phase” and “Epidemic Prevention Events Phase”, players take their turns in clockwise order.

1. Epidemic Prevention and Spread Phase

A. Epidemic Preventionï¼šPlayer takes 3 cards from the top of the card deck, choose one with ï¼»♠/♠ï¼½and place it in any player’s area (include the player himself). Then player flips over the rest of two cards in the “infected area” and check if there is an “outbreak” in “epidemic area”.

Outbreak: After player activates “Epidemic Prevention” and there are the same infected cards in “infected area”, the player must take two same infected cards from “infected area” and place in his player area. Keep taking until infected cards are totally different in the “infected area”.

B. Spread: Take an infected card from the” infected area” and place it in his player area.

2. Epidemic Prevention Events Phase
If the card on the top of the deck withï¼»âœšï¼½, the player activates the card immediately. Next, player flips the card over and places the card in “infected area”. Keep activating every card until there is no more card with ï¼»âœšï¼½on the top of the deck.
After the player finished the phase1 and 2, the player’s turn end. The next player takes his turn in clockwise order.

“Transmission Events”: When all players take their turns, the round ends. Then whoever becomes a “confirmed case” must take a card which should be identical with the routes of infection of his own from the “infected area” to his player area. (about “confirm case”: see the “Special Cases”)

The end of the game:
 1. When the card deck runs out, shuffle the cards of discard area as a new deck. Keep playing the card deck until the deck runs out again, then the game ends. Every player wins the game!

2. If all player become “confirm case” or one player died before players run out the card deck twice, the game ends immediately, all players lose.

Special Cases:
1. “confirm case”: When a player has more than 3 identical infected cards in his player area, he becomes the “confirm case” by that routes of infection. In the end of a round, because of the “Transmission Events”, the “confirm case” has to take a card as same as his routes of infection. But there is no need to take any card if the “confirm case” has the corresponding epidemic prevention card or there is no same infected card in the “infected area”.

2. “death confirmed”: When a player has 5 identical infected cards in his player area, the game ends, everyone is failing to prevent the spread of infectious diseases and is lost.

3. When a player activates “Epidemic Prevention” in his first phase(Epidemic Prevention and Spread Phase) and the 3 cards he draws are all with âœš or he doesn’t want to take anyone back, he may flip over all the cards and place them in “infected area”.

Hospital
A Player who has a hospital card must take the treatment in hospital: he can discard an infected card from his player area every round; he won’t become a “confirmed case” or effect by “Transmission Events”. Before the player discard the hospital card, he can’t activate any action in Phase1. But the player should check if there is an “outbreak” in “epidemic area” as well. If there are more than 2 identical infected cards in “infected area”, the player has to take 2 cards of them and place them in his player area.

—description from the publisher

Poochie Pretty as a Picture Game is a game for 2-4 players, ages 4-8, in which you use your memory and matching skills to collect photos of Poochie and her Pals to fill up your photo album.

Setup the Spinner to the side and lay out a grid of Photo cards face down. Shuffle the cards and place the cards in a 4x4 grid face down, placing the unplaceded cards in a deck next to the grid. refill cards from the deck to the grid when cards are removed. Each player places a "Photo Album" player board in front of them. 
Starting with the youngest player going first.
Spin the spinner to see which of Poochie's Pals you are looking for. Then flip a card to find a match to the character you spun. If you match the spun Character, place it on your Album. If you did not match, flip the card back over. Use your memory skills to remember where cards are to find them later. 
Then the next player takes their turn, repeat.

First player to fill their Photo Album with 6 Photos of Poochie and her Pals Wins. (they do not need to be unique photos to win)

Battles in Deep Space is a two player abstract game of star ship battles.  Players customize their forces by picking four ships out of the twelve options.  Each ship has it's own unique move pattern, attacks with one three dice options, and some have special abilities.

On a player's turn they move one of their ship and then they may attack with a ship.  The attacking ship does not have to be the moving ship.  Attacks are resolved by rolling a six-sided, eight-sided, or ten-sided die.  Hits are scored on a six or higher.  The first player to destroy all of the other player's ships wins.

—user summary

The Tartarus III space station transmitted a distress message. For several years, researchers have been secretly developing a biological weapon to end the war against the Veleptors. But the enemy seems to have penetrated the premises ... Corporal Wedoski and his squad are being sent to recover the pathogen. An impossible mission. A routine mission for the Space Unit.

Space Unit is a comic combined with a game, one title in a series subtitled "The comic in which you are the hero". You embody a character in a immersive story in which your choices guide your progress. You have a character sheet akin to those used in role-playing games that tracks your possessions, your special abilities, your coins, and your victory points. In general, gameplay consists in following the comic's panels — which contain clues, riddles and traps — and making choices about where to go and what to do, while using your visual perception to collect clues and be smart enough to resolve the riddles. As in any game, you can lose — sometimes really badly!

—description from the publisher

A game to record the fight against the 2019-nCoV
A new way of identification. In the game, cards connect players closely.
Each player holds scattered information, and finally builds his own most confident route through communication. The game idea comes from "Ask for directions" in Life.

—description from the designer

Football sports game put out by Standard Oil. Uses a list of offensive and defensive plays to select from to determine the play’s results. Heavy cardboard stock board. No box.

—user summary

There is a dangerous virus outbreak and the authorities have instructed people to minimize their social activities and stay at home as much as possible for at least 14 days (the virus’s incubation period) while they decide on how to deal with the situation.

You are a group of coworkers trying to handle the whole situation. Will you stay at home or will you continue to work? And are you going to be taking any precautions when you go out?

Will you manage to spend these 14 days without infecting each other?

14 Days is a cooperative party game for 3-6 players in which you have to spend 14 days helping prevent the virus’s spread. You win all together (even if some of the players end up getting the virus) if at least one player at the end of the game is not infected!

Designer's Note: A virus outbreak (especially one as critical as the 2020 Coronavirus outbreak) is a very serious matter. The game does not treat it lightly. Instead it tries to educate people on the threat and how to best handle such a situation: staying at home and taking necessary precautions when going out.

—description from the designer

In many countries it is dangerous to be a Christian and they must meet in secret. The government sees them as a major threat and has engaged the secret service. As Secret Service agents conduct house searches, patrol and guard the border, Christians try to smuggle Bibles and do their best to spread the gospel. Who can you trust?

The game if playable for groups of 2-20 players. It is suitable for large groups of 10 to 20 players as a group game and for 2-9 players in the form of a card game! Including an accessible conversation starter from Open Doors about prosecution.

CARDGAME 2-9 players
In the card game for 2-9 players, every player receives a (hidden) role card that decides whether he's in team "believers" or "secret agents". Players also get 3-5 character cards, depending on the amount of players. There are "believers" and "secret agents" among those cards, these are the cards people will try to collect. Most of the other cards are action cards that may help people achieve their goals, like viewing another players role card, forcing other players to discard, grab a specific card from the discard pile or even change your role card with another player to switch teams.

Players will need to make sure that all of the cards in their hand fit their role card to win. When a player only has character cards fitting its role, he wins for the amount of card +2 bonus points. Teammates will be awarded the amount of cards MINUS the character cards fitting their role, making it a valid strategy as well not to collect those cards and actively trying to help their teammates. Players can also collect as many cards from the other team and try to switch to that team. All in all, a rather quick and dynamic card game for 2-9 players.

GROUP GAME 10-20 players
When playing with 10-20 players, it is a role playing game. There's a game leader who hands every player a character card and. The group is basically divided in two (equally strong) teams of believers and secret agents. The game is played in 7 "nights" where every player will close their eyes until they want to perform an action. All players can only choose one action to perform. In general the believers can choose one of two options: either smuggle bibles or try to convert agents. The secret agents can try to stop both. The game leader registers the amount of players for each action. Believers are successful if they gain a majority over the secret agents "defending" and option. Converting secret agents can be a strong strategy because not only it may "create" a new believer, but also reduces the amount of secret agents. However, it is not without dangers: if the secret agents have a majority guarding against that action, it may result in a believer being arrested.

Some of the believers and secret agents have special abilities that may help their teams successfully achieve their goals. Like a detective (secret agent) who can try to arrest believers and a lawyer (believer) who can exonerate them or characters that can gather and communicate extra information. Other special characters make the game even more dynamic, like a "traitor" (starting as a believer but automatically switching to the secret agents after 3 rounds are played) and its "researcher" mirror character (starting as secret agent and becoming a believer after 3 rounds).

Believers win if they successfully smuggle bibles 4 out of 7 rounds or if they convert all secret agents. Secret agents win if they prevent the smuggling of bibles 4 times or if they arrest all believers. 
—description from the designer

You're launching GPS satellites into space. They need to orbit the earth in the correct order. But your launch windows are limited. You can only launch satellites where the spinner points each turn. It is your job to pick the best satellite for each launch to get your birds in order before your opponents.

GPS is a game about how fun it is to spin that spinner. And it is a very satisfying spin.

It is a game about rooting for the rocket to land on your number.

GPS is a game about putting yourself in a position where the spinner is most likely to help you.

—description from the publisher

In Sequoia you are trying to grow the tallest trees in 11 different forests. After your 10 turns, if you have the tallest tree, then you get the victory points from that forest. Second place gets a small consolation prize.

Each turn, you get to grow two of your trees. Which trees you choose will determine if you win or lose. Do you keep fighting in a forest with competition, or start growing your tree somewhere else? You'll have to wrestle with the dice to grow the tree you want.

Sequoia is a game of choosing your battles.

—description from the publisher

The dice will always give you choices, but they will be hard choices.

Ties in each forest are decided by extra tie-breaker rounds that can lead to epic finishes.

Renatio et Gloriam ReG for short

Authors goals (extracted, more at the website):

     create a set of rules that reflects the great change in technology and organisation that was the renaissance, with the increasing sophistication in weapons in terms of both firearms and artillery and the many innovations in how to use them.
     Give the armies a lot of historical character so that you really feel you are leading the Swedes, or the Samurai, or the Poles.
     Create a game where full-sized armies can fight to a conclusion in under 3 hours once players have got over the learning curve. 
     Make the game feel pacey at all stages – in the initial manoeuvre, in the main fight, and at the endgame.
     Make the game come alive by being more interactive and have less time sitting watching somebody else play. 
     Make every mechanism as simple as we can so that we take as much brain-strain out of the mechanics as possible.
     Create a set of rules that allow refights of great battles with a minimum of special rules.
     Embrace modern technology to get away from lists or points systems that are frozen for eternity. 


Online Army lists cover:

     16th Century Europe
     17th Century Europe
     Late 17th and 18th Century Europe
     The New World


—description from publisher (extracts)

Hostage Crisis is a game about teenage love-stories in which one player is out to rescue their lover held hostage and fighting to keep alive hope. The other player will do their best to suppress the rescue attempt at all cost.

The hero will be able to choose among different personality types, stats and equipment that will determine their approach for the rescue mission.

The villain will be able to choose between different characters that impact how the hero will have to go about rescuing their lover, type of enemies and overall mission objective.

—description from the publisher

Board game "Ð“Ð¾Ð´Ð¾" (Godo) - best game for any party! This game develops imagination and creativity. It can be played both in teams or individually.

Goal of the game: score the most points by explaining words in 2 minute, using different methods (speech, drawing, pantomime or using one word). For each method of explanation a different number of points is given.

Gierki MaÅ‚Å¼eÅ„skie: Kalambury (Marriage Games: Charades) is a charades tournament for couples. In 2-4 pairs variant, couples compete with each other. There is also a one couple variant in which partners compete against each other.

There are four types of challenges (described on cards): draw, show, describe using only words starting with "p", draw something whose name begins with a given letter.

Gierki MaÅ‚Å¼eÅ„skie: Kalambury is one of the Gierki MaÅ‚Å¼eÅ„skie ("Marriage Games") series. It is a stand-alone game, but the cards can also be used in the base Gierki MaÅ‚Å¼eÅ„skie game.

—user summary

XXXopoly Pride is an erotic game to be enjoyed by gay and lesbian intimate couples or groups. Explore each other in ways that you have never dreampt possible.  XXXopoly Pride will bring everyone closer together, both literally and figuratively.

The board is divided into four sections. You keep moving around the board trying to purchase as many Sexual Spaces as you can. If you land on a Sexual Space that is owned by someone else you must perform what is on the space. Each space constitutes a sexual action ranging from a kiss all the way up to having intercourse for short periods of time. There are many other erotic activities such as massaging, licking, sucking, and more! Bankrupt your partners to win.

XXXopoly Pride is more special because there are two games in one! It all depends on what you like and which side you prefer! On the blue side, experience the hottest, most erotic gay game ever made. Flip it over and experience the hottest, most sensuous, lesbian game every created. XXXopoly pride has it all!

—description from the game box

These are my 1980's fast play modern naval combat rules.  Whilst the mechanisms are very different to my other rules sets the idea of making them as fast and fun as possible remain the same, even though missile armed warships are by their nature immensely complicated

I am making this set of rules FREE. 2 reasons for this.


     1st I am using them as an introduction to my other rules sets which are all a lot of fun to play and very cheap to buy!  So download for nothing and if they peak your interest check out my other rules sets  put "Dawn Gaming" in the search bar and see what you like, many of them have a free sampler and I cover a number of interesting periods in history.


I am not going to go into great detail about these rules.... they are free!  Just download the whole set.


     And the 2nd reason is that they are not exhaustive, I have put stats in for a number of Soviet and US ships subs and aircraft but this is certainly not an exhaustive set of data.  


If people like the game I may do additional data sets (for free) but you can probably knock your own up anyway.

—description from the designer / publisher

"A Dungeon Crawl Card Game in Space"

Dreams of Typhon is a card game about exploration, cooperation, and a desperate fight for survival. Players take on the role of one of six Survivors that have been trapped on the behemoth space station Typhon as they frantically fight for their lives. Each time the game is played, the layout of Typhon Station changes. Players draw Room Cards to represent their journey through the station. Rooms have various events that could prove to be fatal and may contain a deadly monster known as an Anomaly. However, some rooms contain precious Gear that can be used to level up Survivors to increase their chance of survival.

--publisher's description

For a few extra cookies...

Take on the role of two shameless little critters in their frantic race to steal cookies. Stay sharp and on your guard! There are zookeepers patrolling non-stop and they want nothing more than to get you back in that zoo asap!

Who will get the lion's share of the loot?

Sneak through the dark city streets and stash away as many cookies as you can! But watch out! Your rival... and the zookeepers will try to stop you!

Create a new game board every time thanks to the tile system!

Watch, analyse and plan your greedy heist while keeping an eye on your opponent!

The real satisfaction comes when you have more cookies than them!

- Description from the publisher

How to play ?

On a game board of 25 tiles, move your character to collect as many cookies as possible.

To activate a tile, and collect the cookies it contains, the tile you want must be in the alignment of your pawn and your opponent’s. In other words, always watch the movements of your rival to activate the best tiles.

Activate tiles, unlock special powers (cookie theft, double score, etc.) and beat your opponent. But beware, the guardians of the zoo are watching and can prevent some of your movements.

Be smart, be strategic, be greedy.

The game ends when one of the two players can no longer move his character. A character can no longer move when it can no longer activate any tiles.

Sea Change is a card-laying spatial puzzle for 2 players. It’s a bit like poker reimagined as a strategic, swingy, cutthroat match-3 game.

All you’ll need to play are a standard 52-card deck, some tokens (poker chips, meeples, etc.), and the goal board and 16 goal cards that can be printed and cut out.

In Sea Change, you compete to fulfill poker “hands” – straights, flushes, at the like - in particular geometric arrangements. Say, four cards of the same suit in an “L”. Harder hands will net you more points, but your opponent will also be angling to complete the same goals.

On top of that, each card value has a special power that alters the game rules in interesting ways!

The Second World War saw many new innovations to combat: new weapons from jets to atomic bombs, new tactics and doctrine, and innovations which replaced many old traditions.  
But through it all, the infantryman remained the one indispensable item on the battlefield.  
Even with all the invention and innovation, without the individual doughboy, war still could not be won.

Fire and Maneuver is a 1 to 1 scale game recreating the ground combat of the War.  
No mass tank battles, no ship to ship combat on the high seas, no dog fights at 20,000 feet.  
Just men clawing their way through no-mans land to get to the enemy.

Each figure represents one soldier, one tank, one gun.  
The Scale is small, one inch = 2 yards.  
The combat is fierce, even hand to hand.  
Each tactical move turn lasts only six to thirty seconds, but those few seconds can mean the difference between life and death, victory or defeat.

The game scale works best with 20mm figures (1/72 scale), but will work equally well with 15mm or 28mm.  
Included are two sample scenarios to get you started, as well as charts and stats for most of the common weapons in use through out the later stages of the war.  
The average table size for play is 4x8 feet, about the size of a ping pong table.

Turn Sequence:

     Morale Phase
     Suppressive Fire Phase
     Move / Spot Phase
     Defensive Fire Phase
     Combat Phase


—description from the publisher

End of August 1870. Bazaine and the principal French army have shut themselves up in Metz for a week. The marshal had time to send a message indicating his desire to attempt an exit if a rescue army arrived. But since then, there has been no news. To break the encirclement, Mac Mahon, at the head of the army of Châlons, receives the formal order from the government to rush at Metz to liberate its brothers in arms. The army of Châlons, composed of disparate elements (troops from Africa stand alongside the mobile guards of the Seine), must remain grouped and must move quickly to avoid being taken at the flank by the German troops. The Germans, commanded by Moltke himself, still believe the French to be at Paris, covering the capital. But the city of light is not his objective for the moment. His goal: the destruction of the French regular armed forces in a decisive battle.

Through "Sedan 1870", the evolution of the "Marshals of the 2nd Empire" campaign series, will you be able, like Mac Mahon, to cross the Meuse in time and go to the rescue of Bazaine’s army ? Like Moltke, will you manage to catch the French off guard and definitively vanquish the only enemy regular army still in movement ?


     Complexity : 7/10
     Solo playability : 6/10
     One turn = 1 day
     One counter = 1 division (and 1 SP = 2000 men, 1000 cavaliers or 2 batteries)
     Scale : 10 km between 2 zones


—description from the publisher

This wargame can be linked with "La guerre de 1870" to play the full Campaign of the Imperial War since the beginning of the war until the final decisive battle of Sedan.
(https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/311190/la-guerre-de-1870-la-chute-de-napoleon-iii-juillet)

Help save endangered butterflies! Construction projects in your city are disrupting the natural butterfly habitat. Capture  butterflies and deliver them to protected butterfly gardens in local zoos, botanical gardens, and museums.

The game is played in a series of rounds. Players start each round by playing a card from their hands to determine the round's turn order. Cards are numbered from 0 to 59, and lower numbered cards go first. On a turn, a player captures butterflies from the field and adds them to the jar. When possible, players "deliver butterflies" from their jars to the different butterfly gardens to score victory points (VPs). Which butterflies can be delivered is indicated on the face-up "delivery cards" and players are often in a race to deliver butterflies to take the cards and score points. The player with the most VPs at the end of the game wins.

During the game, players must carefully decide which butterfly cards to play. By playing lowered numbered cards, players not only get a better pick of butterflies in the field, but they also get first chance at delivering butterflies. However, lower numbered butterfly cards usually have fewer butterflies on them, so players cannot add as many to their jars. Also, butterfly cards with special powers usually have high numbers, so you often must sacrifice turn order in order to use one of these special powers.

In this second edition, the artwork and components have been upgraded. A major rule change is a new set-collection aspect of the delivery cards. There are now 4 types of delivery cards and players score a bonus for having a variety. Also, there are some minor rule changes with scoring butterflies in one's hand and jar at game end. Another small change is in the special powers on some of the cards.
  
The maximum number of players in the second edition was lowered to 5 from 6.

Skully Bunnies is a Strategic Battle Royale Playing Card Game.

Gameplay:

Skully Bunnies is a fast paced card game inspired by fusion. Fusion is a process where the player combines cards to create characters with unique abilities. Be the first to fuse all of your Skully Bunnies and show everyone whose house it is! Blast your opponents faces with attack spells or defend yourself with spell cancelling cards. The only questions you must ask yourself is . . .

“Who Will You Fuse?”

—description from the designer

50 historical wargaming scenarios for miniatures featuring battles between the British and German armies in Belgium and France in May-June 1940.

These are all original scenarios. Each scenario is complete and includes the original 1940 map the battle was fought over, the actual troops involved and the missions they had. These are not vague approximations but researched historical simulations.

Optimised for wargaming rules that use one stand = one platoon but easily converted. 
Games range from small encounters to large set piece battles.

—description from the publisher

42 historical wargaming scenarios for miniatures featuring battles between the Belgians and German armies in Belgium in May 1940.

These are all original scenarios. Each scenario is complete and includes the original 1940 map the battle was fought over, the actual troops involved and the missions they had. These are not vague approximations but researched historical simulations. The 18-day campaign in Belgium is given scant study but featured bitter fighting in a wide variety of tactical actions. This volume of scenarios features battles rarely studied and pays tribute to the Belgian's gallant and often over looked efforts.

Optimised for wargaming rules that use one stand = one platoon but easily converted. 
Games range from small encounters to large set piece battles.

—description from the publisher

Paper Pinball is a dice game that tries to capture the feeling of playing pinball. All you will need is a pencil, three dice, and about five minutes.

Each round, roll two dice and fill in one of the scoring zones. Some zones need to be filled in a certain way, and most will cause some sort of effect, so the order you fill them in is important. If you ever can't fill a zone, you'll lose a ball. Lose three balls and the game is over. Try to fill as many scoring zones as possible while triggering multipliers, opening tunnels, and getting the coveted multiball.

—description from the publisher

Under Construction is a roll'n write that puts you in the shoes of builders. Using the dice they will have to make the most points by judiciously placing the figures in the buildings, in order to finish first to get the bonuses. One page game.

Little Village is a PNP, created for Game Jam # 01 Do It Your Game. It is a roll'n write where the players will have to use the dice to build the best possible village, using the right shapes to fulfill the objectives.

æ–¯ãã—ã¦æˆ‘ã¯ç‹¬è£è€…ã«æˆã‚Œã‚Šï¼å¹•æœ«ï¼ (Kakushite ware ha dokusaisha ni nareri, "And Thus I Became a Dictator -Bakumatsu-") is a hidden role game where everyone starts in the same situation and it's possible to play successfully without lying. At the beginning of the game everyone has one of each of seven role cards; over five in-game days, players will give each other votes and discard roles until only one is left, which determines who wins.

Each turn ("day"), a player may choose to either vote or destroy a vote. When you vote you give a vote token to any other player and discard your role cards for the day face down. When you destroy a vote, you discard one vote from any player, including yourself, and your discards for the day are face up. At the end of each of the first three days, all discards are shuffled and revealed in total, so you can follow approximately what cards are still in play.

Roles have a variety of victory conditions.

This game is different from æ–¯ãã—ã¦æˆ‘ã¯ç‹¬è£è€…ã«æˆã‚Œã‚Š (Kakushite ware ha dokusaisha ni nareri, "And Thus I Became a Dictator...") as it includes a set of different cards, winning conditions and theme.

Note: The game can be played with up to 12 players, but one box only supports up to 6. For more than 6 players you will need to buy a second set and combine them.

–user summary

In this game, you have to make a chicken coop by placing fences on the board.
You also have to exclude the fox.
The cards are available in 3 levels.

—user summary

Brain teaser. The henhouse is under attack from the fox in this brain-teaser for one or two players! Who will be the first to work out where to put the barriers to protect the hens from the marauding fox? A game of tactics and thought that also requires a touch of speed!

—description from the back of the box

Witching Weald is a short Programmed movement game for 1-10 players. The game was release as a free print and play for those who were isolated in the COVID-19 outbreak.

The Witching Weald lies deep and dark. Few are those who have ventured in to the heart of its thicket and returned. Even fewer, those who returned with their sanity intact. In the depth of the forest many peculiar ingredients can be found. Some are vital for a witches concoctions and thus their immortality. But not even witches dare walk into the forest in their flesh. Instead they summon their familiars to do their bidding. Witches can only control their familiars for a short period of time. If a witch loses control of her familiar she may lose important ingredients she sought to collect.
Therefore planning ahead is of the essence.

—description from the publisher

In MATCH 5, you just have to find a common link between two icons. Use your imagination to find an answer to each of ten combinations in three minutes. Each combination earns a point.  The player with the most points after 3 rounds, wins.

MATCH 5 is a word game as well as an idea association game, in which players will need to find links between the symbols on the dice. For example, both “Shark” and “Alligator” could be used to link “Carnivore” with “Water”. Coming up with clever answers is a brilliant way to link unusual dice combinations. For example, players could link “Fruit” with “Body part” by using “Adam’s Apple”.

Players have 3 minutes to use their imagination and come up with a creative answer for each of the 10 dice combinations rolled. They must next write down their answers on their notepad sheet.

Digital Mecha Warriors is a game of giant robot tabletop combat.  It is a tactical miniatures game where one player takes the role of the evil Pax Imperialis and the other players are Federation Mecha pilots.  The game has a multiple mission campaign and uses an 8-bit video game art style.

—user summary

In Bandada, you'll travel the world and photograph beautiful birds as you compete against your opponent to see who has the best portfolio by the end. Attract birds with their favorite foods as you use your drafted cards to manipulate twelve dice in three different colors. The unique scoring system on the cards adds an exciting element of strategy as you try to outsmart your opponent and come out on top. 
Will you be the ultimate bird photographer? Play Bandada and find out!

The primary goal of this game design was to reimagine the classic board games "Risk" and "Axis & Allies" by targeting and replacing or eliminating their least enjoyed mechanics and elements, while retaining and building around their best qualities (particularly "Risk".

The game is played on a map of Earth, including all seven continents, broken into 8 different land "Regions" and 6 ocean "Regions". Similar to Risk or A&A, players control factions and compete for power, influence, and resources and use dice to resolve conflicts.

Unlike the parent games, Global War embraces a multi-purpose card system whereby new reinforcements can be claimed OR players can interact and modify dice rolls - even on other player's turns.

Also unlike the parent games, Global War has a "double elimination" mechanic; where a newly eliminated faction enters a "Piracy" stage - where they can utilize the game's built-in naval warfare mechanics to continue influencing the final outcome of the game (and potentially still win!)

The game also has a variety of selectable win conditions and is semi-modular to allow for simpler, quick strategic gameplay, or more complex, longer games that have a similar feel to classic wargaming.

—description from the designer

Spook Mansion is an asymmetrical two player game.
One player is the investigator trying to escape and the other is the house itself attempting to ensure that this does not happen.

The investigator player uses action points to move through the haunted mansion trying to escape as the the house player places cards to expand the house or blocks of exits to draw more cards.

The investigator wins if he escapes before he runs out action points. Three times he can regain all his action points but there is a price, for a ghost will appear.

—description from the designer

Set in feudal Japan, Philosophia: Floating World is a deck-building game which can be played either in turn-taking or fully simultaneous mode. You can build majestic pagodas and Shinto shrines, learn ancient eastern wisdom, explore the world, or fight ancient monsters — or all of the above. This is a sandbox-style game, and how you play is up to you!

In Floating World, you play as one of six unique characters from Edo Japan, each with a unique power and a mysterious secret. The game plays simultaneously over three phases that repeat until one player has gained a victory condition. All phases occur simultaneously, and they are:


    The Draw Phase: Draw six cards from your deck, then pass them to another player. They take these cards, discard one of their choice, then separate the remaining five cards into two piles, one containing two cards and one containing three. You do the same for another player, then take your two piles, discarding one of them and playing the other.
    The Collect Phase: Collect items and bonuses indicated on the cards in your hand. You may also pay time tokens to perform extra actions in the next phase.
    The Action Phase: Simultaneously take actions based on your cards in hand and those that you chose in the collect phase. Disputes caused by the simultaneous nature of these actions are resolved using the influence track, where the player at the top of the track chooses the outcome; choosing in your own interest, however, drops you to the bottom of the track.


Rounds continue in this way until a player gains any of the seven victory conditions available, such as collecting all four ganbaru tokens or discovering another player's secret location and achieving any two of the ganbaru tokens.

Philosophia: Floating World contains over 200 tarot-sized cards and 12 intricate miniatures and is filled with beautiful Ukiyo-e style Japanese art, all digitally remastered to regain the original vibrance of the era. Welcome to the Floating World!

—description from the publisher

Comic Book Crisis is a cooperative worker placement/action game for 1-4 players that can be played on ANY comic book thanks to a patent-pending method.

You play as a member of the heroic B-TEAM, superheroes who attempt to thwart an evil villain's plot. Place your hero's poses onto the comic page, collect resources, and spend them to activate your powers against the villain and their henchmen! If you can work together against the forces of evil before the story reaches its end, you WIN!

Comic Book Crisis comes with four superheroes, each with their own unique pose tokens and deck of power cards. The game also comes with several villains, each of increasing difficulty and their own deck of schemes.

Comic Book Crisis comes with an EXCLUSIVE comic book but the most exciting feature is that thanks to a patent-pending method, COMIC BOOK CRISIS can be played on ANY comic book ever published! You can literally play hundreds of thousands of games of Comic Book Crisis and never have the same experience twice!

—description from the designer

"Operation Rösselsprung" is an anti-partisan operation launched by German forces against the Yugoslav resistance between May 25 and June 3, 1944. This combined operation between the air and ground forces aims to seize - dead or alive - the chief of the resistance Josip Broz known as "Tito", whose hiding place was located in the village of Drvar in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The operational plan, which mobilizes 20,000 soldiers, is the responsibility of the XV Mountain Corps as well as the air forces. The first phase of the raid is led by airborne troops (paratroopers and gliders), the SS-fallschirmjäger battalion 500, a sort of disciplinary battalion. The second phase notably involved the 7th SS Prinz Eugen division, the Brandenburg regiment and its Chetnik subordinates, several reconnaissance Kampfgruppe as well as Croatian forces.

"Operation Rösselsprung 1944" is a solitaire tactical wargame appearing in the French Vae Victis magazine #151 (special game edition). The game is edited under ziplock and contains an A3-size map depicting Drvar (in Bosnia-Herzegovinia) and surroundings, 108 counters (25 counters representing the SS-fallschirmjäger bataillion 500 –- and 54 counters for the communist partisans). The rules are included in a separate 16 pages A5-sized booklet.

The systems uses the improved rules of the "Bruneval 1942" (VaeVictis #104) and "Commando 4 in action: Dieppe 1942" (VaeVictis #131) to simulate the airborne phase of the operation.

This game system developed for the "Raids" series is only playable in solo ; very easy to learn and fun to play ! The "Artificial intelligence" automatically manages Yugoslav actions while the player is in charge of German actions.

The map is point-to-point, one to several hundred meters apart. A game turn is equivalent to 2 hours during the day and 5 hours at night, the scenario begins at 6:00 am on May 25, 1944 and ends at 12:00 am on May 26, that is 12 game turns. One counter represents a full strenght, 35 to 40 German paratroopers, a company of 20 to 100 Yugoslav partisans, an officer, two anti-aircraft machine guns, or two Italian tanks L3-35.

Would you be smart enough to capture Tito, maximize the prizes and minimize your losses ? It’s up to you Captain !

Schmitz 21 is a Blackjack inspired card game where players are playing cards to a collective discard trying to be the one to reach exactly 21.

The game comes with 55 cards: 10 times the numbers 1, 2, 3, 5 and 6 [yes, there is no 4!] and 5 times the number 10.

Each player starts with four cards. A central deck is formed from the rest of the cards. It is played in turn. The player plays one card, calls the total value of all played cards and draws one card. If the sum of the played cards is exactly 21, that player wins all played cards to a face-down pile. A player cannot play a card if the total value would exceed 21. If a player cannot play a card, the previous player wins the played cards.

The game ends when the deck is empty and all hand cards have been played. The player with the most collected cards wins the game.

Wörter Fuchs contains 5 long word dice which have five letters per side. The players have to write down as many valid words as possible using the letters on these dice, until the hourglass (2 minutes) expires. There are two modes to play the game: either take exactly one letter per die or form a pillar from the dice and the letters must be used in the correct order from top to bottom. The player with the most valid words wins. Players with a unique word gain additional points. The number of used dice in the second variant can be varied.

The Vurdes Aerial Combat Institute has emerged as the premier pilot training facility in the galaxy. In order to gain admission, you've passed written tests and aced your interviews, but one final hurdle lies in your path: Adder. Can you best your rivals in this game designed to test your wits and reflexes?

—description from the rulebook


Adder is a real-time strategy dexterity game in which players place cards to extend their own stack of cards to chase and catch the opponent's cards while the opponent is doing the same thing.

—user summary

18 Los Angeles is an 18xx game that has lots of city hexagons packed into a small map, hopefully creating some congestion in rail traffic and competition for tokens. Additionally, there are freight and passenger trains that can share track, which is helpful in the congestion. You’ll need familiarity with, or a copy of, the rules to 1846 to play the game.

1883 Express d'Orient is an 18xx game set between Budapest and Bucharest, players control companies that are headed by different “company presidents”. Two company president cards are randomly assigned at the beginning of the game to each company. These cards give the company a specific ability from phase 2 through phase 4 and another ability from phase 5 until the end of the game. Additional “McGuffins” include giving the players the ability to skip the last train of a type in order to buy the first train of the next type, private companies that pay more revenue once connected to the rail network, and a non-player investor that buys and sells shares based upon the current status of each company. You’ll need familiarity with, or a copy of, the rules to 1830 to play the game.

Constitution Railways
This is an 1846-based game, set in British Columbia.  Differences from 1846 include company-owned track, borders which count against train length, and sea dits.

Forgotten Legends : The Worm Emperor is a high fantasy game set in the magical world of Aiine. Your goal is to prepare a foothold into an uncharted territory and sustain your war effort. Find and defeat the Prince of Despair, his majesty, the Worm Emperor, by breaking the three magic seals which protect his fortress and challenge him to a deadly duel.

Lured by the promise of earthly riches and eternal knowledge in an uncharted region of the realm, the party of Heroes must battle chimeric creatures, flesh and dark thoughts mingled together by magic and molded into fierce monsters born from the depths of a dreadful mind, complete trials which will reveal the very fabric of their soul, fight, scavenge, loot and trade to survive the journey and ultimately face the abominable overlord, the Master of Lies and Prince of Despair, his majesty, the Worm Emperor. 

Replayability : The core of the game is entirely player driven. Heroes decide (individually or as a group) where the game is heading, from fighting an epic monster down to trading and building new dwellings in the castle they settled in. Many paths lead to victory.

 Automa System:  You move, his majesty, the Worm Emperor and his acolytes are moving as well. The enemy army is already on the march to conquer the regions and consolidate the domain of despair. Sooner or later, your armies will meet.

Castles and Outposts: A game within a game. You may start the adventure from any sub-region on the outskirts of the adventure map. Once settled in, you can build new dwellings, trade in the market for items, recruit creatures, complete puzzles and more.

Unique Adventure Map: Divided into three major regions and a fourth special inner region (controlled by the Worm Emperor) and counting more than 65 independent sub-regions the party of Heroes will have the freedom to explore a uniquely designed map with one-of-a-kind characteristics. Conquer cities, acquire resources, uncover mysteries and secret locations.

Modular Battlefield: Constantly changing its configuration depending on the sub-region you are exploring. The setup is randomly created each time your party clashes with a monster or a group of monsters. Terrain obstacles, power-up spots or de-buffs areas will hinder you or help you win the day.

---description from the publisher

Originally it was Time, a tumult of uncontrollable energies, then Space, an infinite fabric in search of a foothold, then Matter arrived as a parasite ready to infest the rules of the Game. Finally she came, blossomed by a tear of light, which gave rise to all living beings, now she has been imprisoned by her power-hungry children and you will have to free her. ETEREA princess has been chained to the heart of the first world, her children, custodians of the six dimensions , they overturned the throne determined to master the fundamental principles to be able to reign over the entire universe. What was once a thriving planet is now a distant memory, that place where life was born has died out, the Vital Essences, now lost, they no longer generate beings and the thread that binds all the galaxies is corroded and close to splitting. The last hope is a handful of Architects, faithful heralds of the princess, designers of all perceptible dimensions and im palpable. Only they will have the ardor to undertake a mission to the limit of the impossible to try to subjugate the six tyrants, take their keys and free ETEREA from an unacceptable fate; if they fail, everything will be lost, the universe, as we know it, will cease to exist giving way to despair, chaos, ruin.

In ETEREA you are one of the architects who will attempt the enterprise to recover the keys, guarded by the six Bosses who govern the six dimensions: Water, Fire, Wind, Earth, Cosmos and Oblivion, to free the princess and save the whole ETEREA is a game divided into two parts: in the first you will have to wander through the six dimensions trying to reconstruct the Requirements, now swept away by the tyrants, to repopulate them; doing this will allow you to acquire Requirement cards and Artifacts, which are essential to succeed in the mission; to create the Requirements you will need careful planning in the dice roll and a careful use of certain skills or Vocations. In the second part you will have to face the Bosses and recover the keys, in doing so you will have to build your dice set , thanks to what I learned in the first part, and launch yourself in a desperate attempt to defeat them in an unequal duel, but thanks to a careful strategy, nothing will be impossible. There is more, always keep an eye on the time that passes , you will only have eighteen hours, a single day on ETEREA, then everything will be lost. Only an Architect will be able to succeed in the heroic action, but everyone will be able to perish in battle leading everything known to ruin. Good luck, that the glow of ETEREA accompany you.

—description from the publisher
